src:
Sánchez entona al fin algo parecido a una disculpa: "La Fiscalía es autónoma, no fui preciso"
> "Son muchas entrevistas, muchas horas... algunas veces no se es preciso", dice para explicar su fallo> Dice que es "humilde", pero que su "trayectoria" es de respeto a la autonomía de la Fiscalía y el Poder Judicial

07 Nov 2019, 13:25

El presidente del Gobierno en funciones, Pedro Sánchez, ha entonado una especie de 'mea culpa' y ha rectificado tímidamente en una entrevista en 'Al Rojo Vivo' de La Sexta tras sus polémicas declaraciones de ayer sobre la Fiscalía, en las que aseguró que dependía del Gobierno y que daría instrucciones para traer a España a Carles Puigdemont.
"El nombramiento de la Fiscalía depende del Gobierno de España efectivamente, pero es autónoma", matizó, a preguntas recurrentes del periodista Antonio García Ferreras. Admitió que no fue "preciso en la afirmación" y lo ha achacado al cansancio de la campaña electoral: "Son muchas entrevistas, muchas horas frente a un micrófono, frente a una pantalla, algunas veces no se es preciso".
A pesar de ello, ha querido destacar que ha sido un presidente que siempre "ha respetado tanto la autonomía de la Fiscalía como la independencia del Poder Judicial": "Si hay que ser humilde, la trayectoria que he tenido como presidente del Gobierno ha sido precisamente esa, la de respetar tanto la autonomía de la Fiscalía como la del Poder Judicial".
"Lo que quise decir es que, desde luego, no hay nadie por encima de la Ley, que hay una sentencia del Tribunal Supremo que claramente señala a líderes independentistas que ahora mismo están huidos de la Justicia española y que por tanto, en un estado social y democrático de derecho, a lo que se compromete el Poder Ejecutivo es a ayudar a la Fiscalía a que estos líderes independentistas vuelvan a España y rindan cuentas ante la Justicia", ha apuntado.
Sobre sus palabras en el debate electoral en las que se comprometió a "traer a Puigdemont a España", ha matizado que "son expresiones que se utilizan en los debates electorales": "Lo que quise decir es el compromiso del Gobierno de España para que las sentencias se cumplan". Además, ha insistido que "la responsabilidad" del Ejecutivo es "ayudar a la Fiscalía y al Poder Judicial".


Borrell defiende a Sánchez: "La Fiscalía tiene autonomía, pero no es independiente"
text:
Sanchez finally sings something similar to an apology: "The Prosecutor's Office is autonomous, I was not precise"
> "There are many interviews, many hours ... sometimes it is not necessary," he says to explain his ruling> He says he is "humble", but that his "career" is respecting the autonomy of the Prosecutor's Office and Power Judicial

07 Nov 2019, 13:25

The president of the acting Government, Pedro Sánchez, has sang a kind of 'mea culpa' and has timidly rectified in an interview in 'Al Rojo Vivo' of La Sexta after his controversial statements yesterday about the Prosecutor's Office, in which he assured that It depended on the Government and would give instructions to bring Carles Puigdemont to Spain.
"The appointment of the Prosecutor's Office depends on the Government of Spain effectively, but it is autonomous," he added, to recurring questions from journalist Antonio García Ferreras. He admitted that he was not "precise in the statement" and has blamed him on the tiredness of the election campaign: "There are many interviews, many hours in front of a microphone, in front of a screen, sometimes it is not necessary."
Despite this, he wanted to highlight that he has been a president who has always "respected both the autonomy of the Prosecutor's Office and the independence of the Judiciary": "If you have to be humble, the trajectory that I have had as President of the Government has been precisely that, to respect both the autonomy of the Prosecutor's Office and that of the Judiciary. "
"What I meant is that, of course, there is no one above the Law, that there is a ruling from the Supreme Court that clearly points to independent leaders who are now fleeing from the Spanish Justice and therefore, in a state social and democratic law, to which the Executive Branch is committed is to help the Prosecutor's Office to return these independence leaders to Spain and be accountable to Justice, "he said.
On his words in the electoral debate in which he promised to "bring Puigdemont to Spain", he has clarified that "they are expressions that are used in electoral debates": "What I meant is the commitment of the Government of Spain to the sentences are fulfilled ". In addition, he insisted that "the responsibility" of the Executive is "to help the Prosecutor's Office and the Judiciary."


Borrell defends Sánchez: "The Prosecutor's Office has autonomy, but is not independent"
